p: Honey has been used to treat wounds beginning from ancient times [ 120]. This practice was rooted primarily in tradition and folklore when investigators began to explore its medicinal potential [ 121]. The honey from different geographical areas has been reported to have considerable therapeutic effects on chronic wounds, ulcers and burns [ 122]. A study reported that honey has almost equal or slightly superior effects compared with conventional treatments for acute wounds and superficial partial-thickness burns [ 3]. Tualang, Gelam and Kelulut honeys have been demonstrated to have wound-healing properties, as listed in Table 9. Their wound-healing mechanism is provided in Figure 5.
